segments.text: Good God.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Do you think it's them?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I wonder.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Nobody knows we're here except Freda and she wouldn't ring up.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It must be them then.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well what are we going to do?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: We'll be alright, darling.  Whatever happens, aren't we?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Now and always sweet.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't care then.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It was bound to come sooner or later.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Hello.  Hello.  What?  Wrong number.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Ahh.  It sent shivers up my spine.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: What shall we do if they suddenly walk in on us?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Behave exquisitely.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: With the most perfect poise.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Certainly I shall probably do a court curtsy.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Things that ought to matter dreadfully don't matter at all when one's happy, do they?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What is so horrible is that one can't stay happy.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Don't say that, my darling.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It's true the whole business is very poor joke.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Meaning that sacred and beautiful thing love.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yes, meaning just that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: What does it all mean?  That's what I asked myself in my ceaseless quest for ultimate truth.  Dear God what does it all mean?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm serious.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You mustn't be serious, my darling.  It's just what they want.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Who's they?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Laugh at them, be flippant, laugh at everything, all their sacred shibboleths
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: flippancy brings out the acid in their damn sweetness and light.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: If I must laugh at everything, I must laugh at us too.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Certainly you must.  We are figures of fun alright.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Oh, how long will it last, this ludicrous, over-bearing love of ours?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well who knows?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: We always want to bicker and fight.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No that fire will fade long with our passion.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Oh, dear shall we like that?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It all depends on how well we've played.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What happens if one of us dies?  Does the one that's left still laugh?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yes.  Yes.  with all his might.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well that's serious enough, isn't it?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, no it isn't.  Death is very laughable such a cunning little mystery.  All done with mirrors.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: So is everyone else in the long run.  Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party as much as we can like small quite idiotic little school children.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Let's savor the delight of the moment.  Come and kiss me darling before your body rots and worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't mind what you do, see. you can paint yourself green all over
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: and dance naked in the place Place Vendome and rush away with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Thank you, dear.  The same applies to you except that if I catch you so much as looking at another woman, I'll kill you.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Do you remember that awful scene in Venice?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Which particular one?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The one where you bought that little painted wooden snake and put it on my bed.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Oh, Charles.  That was his name.  Charles he did wriggle so beautifully.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Horrible thing.  I hated it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yes, I know you did.  You threw him out of the window into the Grand Canal.  I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: How long did that row last?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It went on intermittently for days.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your curling irons burnt holes in my dressing gown.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It burnt my comb too and all the towels in the bathroom.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Ah, we were much younger then.  That was a rouser wasn't it?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: That was the first time you ever hit me.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You didn't hit me- I didn't hit you very hard.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Then the manager came in and found us rolling about on the floor biting and scratching like panthers.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I shall never forget his face.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How ridiculous.  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: We were very much younger then.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And very much sillier.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.
segments.speaker: M
